title: Black and Hispanic Job Seekers Still Face Wage Gap in Tech
summary: Candidates identifying as black or Hispanic received lower salary offers than their white and Asian peers, according to new survey. Racial disparities in technology-industry salaries persist despite promises made by many companies to seek out and elevate diverse talent, according to a new survey from Hired Inc.

title: More Than a Dozen U.S. States See Rise in Coronavirus Cases
summary: Joe Biden criticizes Trump's handling of pandemic. • The total number of coronavirus infections in the U.S. surpassed 2.15 million, making up more than a quarter of global confirmed cases, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. More than 445,000 people have died world-wide; more than 117,000 have died in the U.S.

title: T-Mobile Names New CFO to Continue Sprint Integration
summary: Peter Osvaldik, the carrier's accounting chief, is set to take over as finance chief on July 1. T-Mobile US Inc. said its longtime finance chief Braxton Carter is leaving, replacing him with its head of accounting as the carrier integrates Sprint.

title: The Coming Urban Exodus
summary: Failing progressive governance is making daily life too chaotic and stressful in many U.S. cities.. In his speech last weekend to the graduates of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, President Trump said something with which, in normal times, few would disagree: "What has historically made America unique is the durability of its institutions against the passions and prejudices of the moment." Until now.

title: Mnuchin Declares Global Corporate-Tax Talks at an Impasse
summary: More than 100 countries have worked for years to reshape rules for multinationals; dispute over taxing tech companies divides U.S., Europe. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin declared an impasse in international talks on how countries tax multinational corporations, increasing the odds of an escalating trade and tariff dispute in the midst of a global downturn.

title: Seattle's Chaotic 'Autonomous Zone'
summary: Vigilantes rule the Capitol Hill area, while the mayor pretends all is well.. 'Seattle is fine," tweeted Mayor Jenny Durkan on Friday, responding to President Trump's criticism of the anarchist takeover in her city. "Don't be so afraid of democracy," she lectured the president. But who in Seattle voted to cede their neighborhood to armed vigilantes?

title: Black Lives Can Be Very Different
summary: My wife and I grew up 15 miles apart-in different worlds.. Black lives vary. That matters because what is needed now is an understanding of black America. Without it our nation will either again turn a deaf ear to the struggles of black people or thoughtlessly acquiesce to whatever impassioned political programs present themselves in black America's name. In either case black America loses, and therefore America loses.

title: 'From Here to Equality' Review: The Work of Atonement
summary: The case for reparations is not convincing, but it is predicated on the acknowledgment that liberal social policies have not worked.. The idea of compensating the descendants of American slaves for the injustices inflicted on their ancestors, as William A. Darity and A. Kirsten Mullen remind us in "From Here to Equality: Reparations for Black Americans in the Twenty-First Century," is not new. Charles Krauthammer once proposed that the U.S. pay $50,000 to every African-American family of four in exchange for an end to affirmative action. New York Times columnist Ross Douthat proposed $10,000 per person. From 1989 until his resignation in 2017, Michigan Democratic Rep. John Conyers introduced a bill to form a commission to examine the case for reparations in every Congress. Ta-Nehisi Coates called for reparations in a widely read Atlantic article published in 2014. Among 2020 presidential candidates, Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren and, most recently, Joe Biden have all expressed openness to the idea.

title: Google Sets Hiring Goal to Advance Black Executives
summary: CEO Sundar Pichai says he aims to raise the proportion of 'leadership representation of underrepresented groups' overall by 30% by 2025. Google announced a new hiring goal to dramatically boost the number of black executives at the search giant.

title: What Covid Models Get Wrong
summary: Focus on the burden on hospitals, not on the oft-mistaken forecasts.. Here we go again. The University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation has issued a new forecast that Covid-19 fatalities would spike over the summer in states that have moved faster to reopen. Cue the media drumbeat for another lockdown. Maybe someone should first explain why the models were wrong about so much the last time.

title: The China-India Clash
summary: The Himalayan border brawl is an opening for closer U.S.-Delhi ties.. Monday's skirmish along the China-India border was the deadliest in decades. It's impossible to confirm what triggered the fighting, but the big picture is clear: Tensions between New Delhi and Beijing are escalating while the latter steps up its regional bullying.

title: A Rebuke on Drug Prices
summary: Trump loses an extralegal gambit to embarrass Big Pharma.. The abuse of presidential power is a bipartisan practice in Washington, so it's no surprise that an appellate court this week rebuked the Trump Administration for an extralegal attempt to browbeat drug makers.

title: Reopen the Economy, More Open Than Ever
summary: For Western democracies to flourish, they must first reject statism as the model for post-Covid governance.. Friedrich Hayek published "The Road to Serfdom" in 1944, but it should be essential reading for all Western leaders today. Just as leaders then needed a rebuttal to the view that wartime centralized planning was superior to the free market and should be continued in peacetime, leaders today must be reminded that statism shouldn't be the model for post-Covid governance.

title: State Taxes Shouldn't Be Another Pandemic Worry
summary: Congress should standardize filing rules to help traveling medical professionals and remote workers.. As New York struggled with tens of thousands of coronavirus cases, medical professionals from across the U.S. traveled to the city to help. Their work was crucial to the city's effort to contain the pandemic and undoubtedly helped save lives. And in May, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced their reward: tax bills from the state of New York.

title: All Hail the Return of TV Sports
summary: European soccer and Saturday's Belmont Stakes are welcome distractions from Covid gloom.. The psychic torment of being confined at home for the past three months has been compounded-for my 20-year-old son and me-by the absence of live sports on television. For us, watching soccer together offers an opportunity not only to shriek and cuss and, very occasionally, dash a fist against a wall, but also to pool our emotions as father and son. "Bonding," I believe, is the American word, but I prefer to see it as communion. In pre-Covid times, we'd get together once or twice a week and lose ourselves (for a couple of hours each time) in feints, tackles, yellow cards and goals-usually watching Spain's soccer league, La Liga, or the English Premier League.

title: Senators Blast FAA for 'Stonewalling' in 737 MAX Document Requests
summary: Lawmakers accuse agency of impeding congressional oversight and failing to embrace proposed legislative changes. The Senate Commerce Committee issued strong bipartisan complaints about what lawmakers alleged has been persistent foot-dragging by the Federal Aviation Administration in providing internal documents related to the agency's initial certification of Boeing Co. 's embattled 737 MAX jets.

title: Pharmacists Add Real Value on Prescriptions
summary: There is a good reason that medicine and pharmacy have been separated as disciplines for centuries.. Regarding your editorial "Letting the Docs Dispense" (June 13): We are highly trained in pharmacology and pharmaceutics, much more than any other member of the health-care team. We verify that patients are receiving the right medication at the right dose that is appropriate and doesn't harmfully interact with other medications. As drug regimens become more complex, these services are more vital, not "needless."

title: Incentives of Special Unemployment Benefits
summary: How can I explain to those employees who were not laid off that their returning co-workers, who were laid off, will be receiving an additional, federal, bonus?. In "Don't Cut Off Unemployment Benefits Now" (op-ed, June 9), Alan S. Blinder lists a way to reprogram unemployment benefits by paying a "back to work" bonus for a time.

title: If Mayhem Is the Message, What's the Response?
summary: We are told that "silence is violence" (if we don't loudly espouse the radical left's canned talking points). So, both speaking out and not speaking at all can be "violence.". In "The Mayhem Is the Message" (Main Street, June 9), William McGurn quotes Scott Walter on the thorough distortion of language by the radical left in order to dominate our society's moral and political conversation. On campus, the mob cries "speech is violence" (when the speech disagrees with their ideology); street mobs insist "violence is speech" (if it allows looting, torching of businesses, etc.). Messrs. McGurn and Walter both overlook the third leg of the radical language toolset, i.e., we are also told that "silence is violence" (if we don't loudly espouse the radical left's canned talking points). So both speaking out and not speaking at all can be "violence."

title: Whatever Happened in Georgia, It Wasn't Voter Suppression
summary: While losing to Mr. Kemp in 2018, Ms. Abrams significantly outpolled Sen. David Perdue, who won his Senate seat in 2014 with 1,358,088 votes in 2014. The voter turnout in 2018 exceeded the voter turnout in 2014 by 1,383,194.. Barton Swaim's review of Stacey Abrams's "Our Time is Now" (Bookshelf, June 10) refers to Ms. Abrams's devotion to the "voter suppression" argument, including how she used it when running against Republican Brian Kemp, and continued to use it after she lost.

title: The Australians Pioneered Remote Education Long Ago
summary: For over 50 years, predating the internet, the Australian School of the Air has provided effective lower- and middle-grade education to isolated children in the Outback.. Andy Kessler ("Give Online Learning an Upgrade," Inside View, June 1) is absolutely correct in the position that distant education works and is effective. For over 50 years, predating the internet, the Australian School of the Air has provided effective lower- and middle-grade education to isolated children in the Outback. It isn't the distance between the teacher and the student that matters. It is the dedication of the student, the family and the teacher to learning that achieves desired results.

title: Exercise Dresses: Fun or Foolish?
summary: Some women swear by the functionality and style of working out in stretchy dresses. Others are more ambivalent.. Instead of the standard shorts and top, the 24-year-old graphic designer wore a leopard-printed dress to navigate the 26.2-mile-long course. title: Bolton Savages Trump's China Policy
summary: The president pleaded with Chinese leader Xi Jinping for domestic political help, subordinated national-security issues to his own re-election prospects and ignored Beijing's human-rights abuses. U.S. strategy toward the People's Republic of China has rested for more than four decades on two basic propositions. The first is that the Chinese economy would be changed irreversibly by the rising prosperity caused by market-oriented policies, greater foreign investment, ever-deeper interconnections with global markets and broader acceptance of international economic norms. Bringing China into the World Trade Organization in 2001 was the apotheosis of this assessment.

summary: Some retailers are putting aside large portions of inventory to avoid selling into an aggressively promotional sale environment. Apparel companies have had it with sales.

title: Goodhart Partners Raises Its Stake in Private-Equity Firm CapitalSpring
summary: The London asset management firm, which acquired a minority interest in restaurant-focused CapitalSpring in April, is buying out other minority investors. Goodhart Partners is increasing its stake in CSFC Management Co., which does business as CapitalSpring, less than two months after acquiring its initial stake in the restaurant-focused private investment firm.

title: One Government Bond Market the Rally Didn't Reach
summary: There are a number of good reasons to expect the Chinese government bond market to provide returns in the long term and diversification in the short term. Even as relations between the U.S. and China deteriorate, threatening economic ties, there is still a long-term opportunity for American investors in the country's government bond market.

title: TikTok Users Gush About China, Hoping to Boost Views
summary: Company says it doesn't favor paeans to Beijing like 'ilovechina'. It wasn't dancing or music that powered Texas songwriter TJ Asaday toward TikTok stardom. He believes it was a video about his love for China.

title: Biotech Startups Look to Test Employees in Bid to Get Back to Normal
summary: Biotechnology companies are proceeding cautiously about bringing scientists back into the lab. Biotechnology startups are seeking to test employees for Covid-19 and taking other precautions to protect laboratory workers as they move to resume more normal operations.

title: Tesla Registrations Plunge in California, Data Tracker Says
summary: Drop of 37% in largest U.S. market highlights coronavirus impact and the pressure on Elon Musk to maintain momentum on deliveries. Registrations of newly purchased Tesla Inc. vehicles plunged in the critical California market over the past two months, according to new data, underlining the challenge Chief Executive Elon Musk faces to keep investor enthusiasm that has helped propel the company's share price.

title: Insurers Hit Brakes on Investments Designed to Make Risky Loans Safe
summary: CLOs-popular investments tied to pools of corporate loans-are proving riskier than many insurance firms expected. Insurance companies helped fuel the boom in a corner of the debt market that sliced and diced risky corporate loans. Those bets are now starting to hurt, crimping a key source of financing for Wall Street's deal-making machine.

title: Pressure Builds to Name PPP Borrowers
summary: SBA faces demands from government auditors, media companies and Democratic and GOP lawmakers. WASHINGTON-Pressure is building on the Trump administration to disclose the names of borrowers that received loans through the Paycheck Protection Program, and a key senator signaled that the names of larger loan recipients could be released.

title: The Car Industry's $1.1 Trillion Debt Problem
summary: Pandemic shutdowns have hit auto makers and their suppliers at a point when balance sheets were already under pressure. The acute phase of the coronavirus crisis has passed for automakers. The chronic phase may be just beginning.

title: European Car Makers Face Glut of Unsold Vehicles
summary: Germany's incentives that focus on electric vehicles are criticized as failing to address oversupply. BERLIN-After reopening factories and sorting out supply chains, Europe's car makers are facing a new problem related to the coronavirus pandemic: a glut of unsold cars.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: TV Sports Executives Warm to Canned Crowd Noise but Give Viewers an Out
summary: Broadcasters try to make sure purists can avoid recorded crowd roars as sports leagues play to empty stadiums. One weekend last month, James Sexton streamed a soccer game on his phone at home in the southwest of England. The German Bundesliga match was one of the first since the new coronavirus halted live sports around the world, as well as one of the first of what Germans call "Geisterspiele," or "ghost games" played in empty stadiums and robbed of the roar of the crowd, amid social-distancing rules.

title: U.S. Files Breach-of-Contract Suit Against Ex-National Security Adviser John Bolton
summary: Suit claims Bolton would compromise national security by publishing book it says contains classified information. The U.S. on Tuesday filed a breach-of-contract lawsuit against former national security adviser John Bolton, seeking to delay the publication of his book, which the suit alleges contains classified information that could compromise national security.

title: Facebook Aims to Register 4 Million U.S. Voters
summary: Social media company rolls out voting information initiative, political ad controls. Facebook Inc. aims to register 4 million voters before the November presidential election, as well as offer voting information and political ad controls as the social media giant grapples with ongoing controversy over what to allow on its platforms.

title: Global Coronavirus Infections Pass Eight Million
summary: Confirmed cases in more than a dozen U.S. states rose in the past week more quickly than in the previous week. • Texas, Arizona and North Carolina reported record daily coronavirus-related hospitalizations, as confirmed cases in more than a dozen U.S. states rose in the past week more quickly than in the previous week. At least 2.13 million people in the U.S. have been infected with the new coronavirus, making up about a quarter of global confirmed cases, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Nearly 439,000 people have died world-wide.

title: Supreme Court Grants Texas Inmate Reprieve From Execution
summary: With stay, high court has opportunity to set standard for religious rights of prisoners about to die. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court blocked Texas from executing a man Tuesday so the justices could consider the inmate's plea to have a chaplain accompany him in the death chamber.

title: Founder of Iranian Company Accused of Sanctions Violations Pleads Guilty
summary: Seyed Sajjad Shahidian, founder of Payment24, was charged with helping Iranian citizens conduct prohibited financial transactions with businesses in the U.S.. An Iranian businessman accused of conducting financial transactions that violated U.S. sanctions has pleaded guilty, the U.S. Justice Department said Tuesday.
